newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - February 10.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - February 10.

text.p: Following are the highlights of stories reported in the Irish press on Monday.
- More than 5,000 paramedics are expected to press for similar increases to nurses if the nursing unions accept the latest 80 million Irish pound offer from the government.
- A White House spokesman has denied any shift in policy on Northern Ireland which could affect the future of the U.S. ambassador to Ireland, Jean Kennedy Smith.
- The tribunal of inquiry ihto payments to politicians by Dunnes Stores is expected to sit in Dublin Castle, the same venue as the beef tribunal.
- The British government has not completely ruled out contact with Sinn Fein in advance of an IRA ceasefire.
- An agreement struck this weekend by the Group of Seven industrialised nations to try to stabilise the dollar faintly echoes the landmark Louvre accord it reached 10 years ago this month.
- Nursing sources expressed serious doubts on Sunday night that the Labour Court improvements on pay and conditions will be sufficient to prevent a nationwide nursing strike.
- A senior opposition Fianna Fail politician in Ireland on Sunday accused the government of using the Dunnes Stores payments tribunal as "a political gimmick".
- Ireland's Democratic Left leader, Proinsias de Rossa, has challenged the IRA to explain how a renewed campaign of violence has advanced its political objectives.
- Irish prison administration is set to undergo a series of changes following the establishement of an independent prisons board by the government.
- Over 50 percent of Irish workers are not covered by occupational pensions, according to Minister of State at the Department of Social Welfare, Bernard Durkan.
- THe international criminal behind the biggest shipment of cannabis ever seized by Irish police has been arrested in the United States.
- Counterfeit credit cards which can fool electronic checking machines are being used by foreign gang who make regular swoops around Ireland.

- The choices facing the people at this year's general election had been dramatically simplified as a result of "the hard face of the Progress Democrats", according to Labour Leader and Deputy Irish Prime MInister Dick Spring.

- The dollar and sterling could push higher on currency markets this week, causing more problems for the Irish pound in the European grid after what was seen as a weak attempt to rein in the U.S. currency at the weekend G7 meeting in Berlin.
